com.apriori.testing

Class InterfaceVerifier<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.testing.InterfaceVerifier<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The interface implemented by the class under test or Object if testing a class against more than one implemented interface

    public class InterfaceVerifier<T>
extends Object
    An object that can verify an implementation of an interface by comparing its behavior to that of a reference implementation. This can be particularly useful, for example, when creating new implementations of standard interfaces like collections (Collection, List, Map, etc.). One can test that the basic interface methods are implemented correctly by comparing their behavior against known good implementations (e.g. ArrayList, HashMap, etc.).

    When writing tests, create an InterfaceVerifier and configure the way it verifies method invocations as appropriate. Then use it to create an interface proxy. When a method is called on the proxy object, it is dispatched to both the implementation under test and the reference implementation. The proxy will assert that the test implementation behaves correctly, per the configuration for that method.

    By default, methods are verified per the following rules:

    • If the interface method is a mutator method then both objects must match after the method is called. By default, the objects will be compared against one another using Object.equals(Object). But you can supply an alternative ObjectVerifier that can determine if the test object has correctly mutated in the same way as the reference object.

      By default, mutator methods are assumed to be all methods on the interface that return void, but this can be overridden by configuring methods to be mutator methods (see configureMethod(MethodSignature) and InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration.mutator() for more details).

      Also, if the two implementations implement Object.hashCode() using the same scheme, their hash codes can be compared after a mutator method is called to ensure that they match, too (see setCheckHashCodesAfterMutation(boolean) for more details).

    • If the interface method has a non-void return type then the return values of both the test and reference implementation will be compared to make sure the method behaved correctly. By default, there are a few options for how the invocation handler will perform that check:
      1. If the return type specified for the method is an interface then the verifier used will make sure that if one implementation returns null that they both return null and then return a proxy for that interface as well, in order to subsequently test the implementation of returned interfaces. This verifier is created using ObjectVerifiers.forTesting(Class).
      2. If the return type specified for the method is not an interface (i.e. it is a primitive or a class) then the verifier used will check that the test implementation returns the same values as the reference implementation. By default the return values are compared using the ObjectVerifiers.EQUALS verifier.
      The default verifier used for any given method can be overridden by configuring the methods (see InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration.returnVerifier(ObjectVerifier) for more details).
    • If the method on the reference implementation throws an exception then the method under test should also throw a similar exception.

      By default, the proxy will use strict checking of the exception: the test implementation must throw an exception whose class is the same as the exception thrown by the reference implementation. You can configure the proxy to use relaxed exception checking, in which case the test implementation must throw either a sub-class (descendant class) of the exception thrown by the reference implementation or a sibling class. A sibling exception class simply has a common ancestor with the exception thrown by the reference implementation, and the ancestor must be one of the checked exceptions in the interface method's signature (see setDefaultExceptionVerifier(ObjectVerifier) and InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration.exceptionVerifier(ObjectVerifier) for more details).

      In the event that both implementations throw RuntimeExceptions, but not precisely the same concrete exception class, then you can still use the relaxed exception handling, but you must define the ancestor exceptions that can be thrown since RuntimeExceptions are not generally included in the method's signature (see InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration.uncheckedExceptions(Set) for more details).

    The behavior that is configured per method is actually defined using MethodSignatures. In cases where multiple interfaces for a test object are being verified, it is possible more than one interface have methods with the same signature. Such a method's configuration will be the same, regardless of which of the interfaces was used to invoke the method. So the configuration is defined per signature, not per individual interface method. In cases where multiple methods have the same signature but different return types, the most specific return type will be used to determine the default behavior for that method (i.e. whether it uses object verifiers to check for matching return values or if it instead creates proxies for verifying implementation of returned interfaces).

    Author:
    Joshua Humphries (jhumphries131@gmail.com)

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified class tokens does not represent an interface
        NullPointerException - If the specified interface is null

      • InterfaceVerifier

        public InterfaceVerifier(Class<? extends T>... interfaces)
        Constructs a new verifier for one or more interfaces.
        Parameters:
        interfaces - The interfaces whose implementations will be verified
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no interfaces are specified, if any of the specified class tokens does not represent an interface, or if the interfaces are incompatible (they have a method with the same signature but different and incompatible return types)
        NullPointerException - If any of the specified interfaces are null

      • InterfaceVerifier

        Parameters:
        interfaces - The interfaces whose implementations will be verified
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no interfaces are specified, if any of the specified class tokens does not represent an interface, or if the interfaces are incompatible (they have a method with the same signature but different and incompatible return types)
        NullPointerException - If the set of interfaces is null or if any of the specified interfaces therein are null

    • Method Detail

      • setDefaultMutatorVerifier

        public void setDefaultMutatorVerifier(ObjectVerifier<? super T> v)
        Sets the default verifier used to verify the implementations of mutator methods. Individual mutator methods can override this default verifier.
        Parameters:
        v - the new default verifier
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified verifier is null

      • getDefaultMutatorVerifier

        public ObjectVerifier<? super T> getDefaultMutatorVerifier()
        Returns the default verifier used to verify the implementations of mutator methods. By default, this verifier will be ObjectVerifiers.EQUALS.
        Returns:
        the default verifier for mutations

      • setDefaultExceptionVerifier

        public void setDefaultExceptionVerifier(ObjectVerifier<Throwable> v)
        Sets the default verifier used to verify the exceptions thrown by methods. Individual methods can override this default verifier.
        Parameters:
        v - the new default verifier
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the specified verifier is null

      • setStrictDefaultExceptionVerifier

        public void setStrictDefaultExceptionVerifier()
        Sets the default verifier used to verify the exceptions thrown by methods to use strict checking. Individual methods can override this default verifier. The strict checking verifier is ObjectVerifiers.STRICT_EXCEPTIONS.

      • setRelaxedDefaultExceptionVerifier

        public void setRelaxedDefaultExceptionVerifier()
        Sets the default verifier used to verify the exceptions thrown by methods to use relaxed checking. Individual methods can override this default verifier. The relaxed checking verifier is built using ObjectVerifiers.relaxedExceptions(Set) and can actually vary from one method to another, depending on the exceptions thrown by a method.

      • getDefaultExceptionVerifier

        public ObjectVerifier<Throwable> getDefaultExceptionVerifier()
        Returns the default verifier used to verify exceptions thrown by methods. By default this verifier will be ObjectVerifiers.STRICT_EXCEPTIONS.

        This method returns null if the default verifier is using relaxed checking. This is because no single verifier is used. Instead, a verifier is created per method, based on the actual exceptions thrown by that method (both declared/checked exceptions as well as configured unchecked exceptions).

        Returns:
        The default verifier for thrown exceptions or null if relaxed checking is the default

      • setCheckHashCodesAfterMutation

        public void setCheckHashCodesAfterMutation(boolean check)
        Sets whether hash codes are verified after mutator methods are invoked.
        Parameters:
        check - If true then hash codes will be verified after mutations

      • isCheckHashCodesAfterMutation

        public boolean isCheckHashCodesAfterMutation()
        Returns whether hash codes are verified after mutator methods are invoked. By default this is false.
        Returns:
        True if hash codes are verified after mutations

      • setSuppressExceptions

        public void setSuppressExceptions(boolean suppress)
        Sets whether exceptions should be suppressed during method invocation. This defaults to true. When true, methods that raise exceptions will instead return null.

        This can be useful when writing large tests so that lengthy try-catch blocks don't have to be included to describe cases that are expected to raise exceptions.

        Parameters:
        suppress - True if exceptions should be suppressed
        See Also:
        getLastException()

      • isSuppressExceptions

        public boolean isSuppressExceptions()
        Returns true if exceptions will be suppressed during method invocations. By default this is true.
        Returns:
        True if exceptions will be suppressed

      • getLastException

        public Throwable getLastException()
        Returns the exception thrown during the most recent method invocation or null if the most recent invocation did not throw an exception. This returns the excpetion thrown by the implementation under test. So if the reference implementation threw an exception but the test implementation did not, this would return null.

        This can be used when exceptions are suppressed to easily access thrown exceptions without having to write verbose try-catch expressions.

        Returns:
        The most recently thrown exception or null

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets the verifier to the default configuration. All configuration for how this object handles and tests method invocations will be as if the object had just been created.

      • getMethodNamed

        public MethodSignature getMethodNamed(String methodName)
        Gets the method with the specified name that is supported by this interface verifier. If there are no methods with the specified name, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The method name
        Returns:
        The method with the specified name or null
        Throws:
        TooManyMatchesException - If more than one method has the specified name

      • getMethodsNamed

        public Set<MethodSignature> getMethodsNamed(String methodName)
        Gets all methods with the specified name that are supported by this interface verifier. This will return more than one method if the named method is overloaded.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The method name
        Returns:
        The set of supported methods with the specified name

      • findMethod

        public MethodSignature findMethod(String methodNamePattern)
        Finds a method whose name matches the specified search string. The string can include wildcard characters like "?" and "*". If there are no methods with matching names, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        methodNamePattern - The search pattern
        Returns:
        The method with a name that matches the specified pattern or null
        Throws:
        TooManyMatchesException - If more than one method name matches the specified pattern

      • findMethods

        public Set<MethodSignature> findMethods(String methodNamePattern)
        Finds all methods whose names match the specified search string. The string can include wildcard characters like "?" and "*". This can return multiple matching methods with the same name if a matching method name is overloaded.
        Parameters:
        methodNamePattern - The search pattern
        Returns:
        The set methods with a name that matches the specified pattern

      • getMethod

        public MethodSignature getMethod(String methodName,
                        Class<?>... args)
        Gets the method with the specified signature. This is similar to constructing a new method signature with the specified name and argument types except that if no such method is supported by this invocation handler then this method returns null.
        Parameters:
        methodName - The method name
        args - The method's parameter types
        Returns:
        The method signature matching the specified name and parameter types or null

        Returns:
        A method capturer for this verifier's interfaces

        Returns:

        public Set<MethodSignature> allMethodSignatures()

        Returns:

      • configureMethod

        public InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T> configureMethod(MethodSignature sig)
        Returns the configuration for the specified method. The configuration can be used to change the configuration of how invocations of that method are verified.
        Parameters:
        sig - The signature of the method to configure
        Returns:
        The configuration for the specified method signature
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified method is not supported by this handler (i.e. not a method on any of the handler's interfaces)
        NullPointerException - If the specified method is null

      • configureMethods

        public InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> configureMethods(MethodSignature... sigs)
        Returns a configurator for configuring multiple methods at the same time. All configuration changes are applied to all of the specified method signatures. If configuration changes are invalid for any of the included methods then an exception will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        sigs - The signatures of the methods to configure
        Returns:
        A configurator for configuring all specified methods at once
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If any of the specified methods is not supported by this handler (i.e. not a method on any of the handler's interfaces) or if no methods are specified
        NullPointerException - If any of the specified methods are null

      • createProxy

        public T createProxy(T testImpl,
            T referenceImpl)
        Creates a proxy object. Methods on the proxy are handled by an invocation handler that dispatches to the test and reference implementations for verifying the functionality of the test implementation.

        The current object's class loader (this.getClass().getClassLoader()) is used to define the proxy.

        Parameters:
        testImpl - The test implementation
        referenceImpl - The reference implementation
        Returns:
        The proxy object
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If any of the interfaces to be implemented by the proxy are not visible by name through the current object's class loader

      • createProxy

        public T createProxy(T testImpl,
            T referenceImpl,
            ClassLoader classLoader)
        Creates a proxy object. Methods on the proxy are handled by an invocation handler that dispatches to the test and reference implementations for verifying the functionality of the test implementation.
        Parameters:
        testImpl - The test implementation
        referenceImpl - The reference implementation
        classLoader - The class loader used to define the proxy
        Returns:
        The proxy object
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If either of the implementations does not implement all required interfaces or if any of the interfaces are not visible by name through the specified class loader
        NullPointerException - If either of the implementations specified is null

      • verifierFor

        public static <T> InterfaceVerifier<T> verifierFor(T proxy)
        Returns the InterfaceVerifier for configuring the specified proxy object. This is particularly useful for configuring the verification of returned interfaces.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The interface that the proxy implements
        Parameters:
        proxy - The proxy
        Returns:
        The invocation handler for the proxy
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified object is not actually a proxy or if it is a proxy that was not created using createProxy(T, T)
        NullPointerException - If the specified proxy is null
        See Also:
        ObjectVerifiers.forTesting(Class)

      • copyFrom

        public void copyFrom(InterfaceVerifier<T> other)
        Copies the configuration from another verifier. This can be useful when testing a whole graph of related interfaces. In such a case, you could configure verification of all interfaces in a set-up step using multiple InterfaceVerifiers. Additional verifiers will be created during method calls that return interface types (for subsequent verification of returned interfaces). You can then quickly configure those verifiers by copying the configuration defined during set-up using this method.
        Parameters:
        other - A verifier whose configuration will be copied into this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified verifier does not support exactly the same set of interfaces as this
